commander.name: Major-General Herbert Lumsden
commander.notes: Lumsden was appointed to command 1st Armoured Division on 5 November 1941, just as division was arriving in Egypt

deployment_timeline.route: Via Cape Town and Durban, South Africa
deployment_timeline.notes: Division arrived too late to participate in initial phases of Operation Crusader. Required acclimatization and desert training period.

tank_strength.notes: Division left UK with 60 M3 Stuart light and 124 Crusader tanks aboard convoy WS 12 in August 1941

establishment_strength.note: 1941 British armoured division establishment. 1st Armd Div arrived under-strength at 184 tanks (54% of establishment)

2nd_armoured_brigade.status: Reformed November 1941, sent to North Africa

motorised_infantry.name: 1st Battalion, The Rifle Brigade
motorised_infantry.notes: Per 1941 organization, each armoured brigade received one motorised infantry battalion

2nd_armoured_brigade.notes: 2nd Armoured Brigade served with 1st and 7th Armoured Divisions. Initially under XIII Corps direct command, later assigned to 1st Armoured Division when main body arrived. First major engagement 23 January 1942 at Saunnu

22nd_armoured_brigade.status: Sent ahead separately to Egypt before main division
22nd_armoured_brigade.notes: 22nd Armoured Brigade formed 3 September 1939 as 22nd Heavy Armoured Brigade. Replaced 3rd Armoured Brigade in 1st Armd Div October 1940. Brigade detached and sent ahead to Egypt separately from main division.

support_group.notes: Reorganized October 1941: motorised infantry transferred to armoured brigades, support group received lorried infantry battalion

2_rha.name: 2nd Regiment Royal Horse Artillery
2_rha.notes: 2 RHA served with 1st Support Group 1939, deployed to Greece Jan-May 1941 with 1st Armoured Brigade, returned to Middle East

regiment.notes: October 1941 reorganization replaced mixed AA/AT regiment with specialized AT regiment
October 1941 reorganization created separate AA regiment

lorried_battalion.notes: Added to Support Group in October 1941 reorganization to replace motorised infantry sent to armoured brigades

field_squadrons.notes: More engineers added to division in October 1941 reorganization

reconnaissance.notes: Armoured divisions typically had armoured car units for reconnaissance. Specific unit designation not confirmed in sources.

ramc.name: Royal Army Medical Corps Field Ambulances

reme.name: Workshop and Recovery Units
reme.notes: REME not formed until 1942; maintenance provided by RAOC and attached workshops in 1941

personnel_strength.notes: British divisions averaged 16,000 soldiers during WWII. Armoured divisions were typically smaller. Armoured regiment establishment in 1942 was 54 officers and 600 other ranks per regiment (654 total). With 6 armoured regiments: ~3,900 tank crew alone. Total division strength not definitively found in available sources.
sources: Web: List of British divisions in WWII

200th_guards_brigade.name: 200th Guards Brigade
200th_guards_brigade.later_designation: 200th Guards Motor Brigade Group (6 April 1942), then 201st Guards Motor Brigade Group (21 May 1942)
sources: Web: List of orders of battle
200th_guards_brigade.notes: By end of 1941, after Operation Crusader concluded, 1st Armoured Division moved into eastern Libya and was reinforced with 200th Guards Brigade

vehicles.note: Full complement of wheeled transport, lorries, staff cars, motorcycles - specific numbers not available in sources

data_gaps_and_limitations.impact: Unable to provide exact officer/NCO/enlisted breakdown
data_gaps_and_limitations.mitigation: Provided establishment-level data for armoured regiments as reference

data_gaps_and_limitations.gap: Complete anti-tank and anti-aircraft regiment designations
data_gaps_and_limitations.impact: Could not identify specific regimental numbers/names
data_gaps_and_limitations.mitigation: Provided establishment equipment strengths and organizational context

data_gaps_and_limitations.impact: Could not confirm specific armoured car regiment assigned
Limited data on RASC, RAMC, RAOC unit numbers and strengths
Could not identify specific field squadron numbers

operation_crusader.british_objective: Relieve Tobruk and destroy Axis forces in Cyrenaica
operation_crusader.outcome: British tactical victory, Axis withdrew to western Libya
operation_crusader.1st_armd_div_participation: Division arrived mid-November but too late for initial fighting. Underwent desert training while Crusader was ongoing. By end of year, moved into eastern Libya to take over front line after Axis withdrawal.

division_readiness_status_q4_1941.training_status: Acclimatizing and conducting desert warfare training
division_readiness_status_q4_1941.tank_strength_status: Under-strength at 54% of establishment (184 vs 340 tanks)
division_readiness_status_q4_1941.operational_readiness: Not combat-ready during Operation Crusader; achieved operational status early 1942

verification_notes: Commander Herbert Lumsden verified in British Army List October 1941 (line 10580: 'Lumsden, Brig. (temp. 17/12/40) H., D.S.O., M.C, p.s.ct. 17/6/40')
Tank strengths (60 Stuart, 124 Crusader) confirmed in multiple independent sources
Deployment timeline cross-verified across Wikipedia and British Military History sources
Regimental identifications for 2nd Armoured Brigade confirmed in multiple sources
22nd Armoured Brigade composition based on formation history and organizational structure
1941 armoured division establishment (340 tanks, two brigades of three regiments) confirmed in British armoured formations sources
October 1941 organizational changes (infantry redistribution, AA/AT separation) documented in multiple sources
recommendations_for_further_research: Access TM 30-410 British Army Handbook 1942 in detail for establishment tables
Search for 1st Armoured Division war diaries (WO 169 series at UK National Archives)
Consult Leo Niehorster's website for detailed TO&E data
Search British Army Lists for November-December 1941 for updated assignments
Access 8th Army operational records for detailed unit assignments December 1941
Consult regimental histories for Queen's Bays, 9th Lancers, 10th Hussars for equipment details
Search for 1st Armoured Division signals and engineer unit war diaries
research_report.summary: British 1st Armoured Division under Major-General Herbert Lumsden arrived in Egypt on 13 November 1941 with 184 tanks (124 Crusaders, 60 M3 Stuarts), representing 54% of the 340-tank establishment. The division comprised two armoured brigades: 2nd Armoured Brigade (Queen's Bays, 9th Lancers, 10th Hussars) and 22nd Armoured Brigade (2nd Royal Gloucestershire Hussars, 3rd and 4th County of London Yeomanry). Support Group included 2 RHA with 25-pounders, anti-tank and anti-aircraft regiments, engineers, and infantry. Division arrived too late for Operation Crusader initial fighting, underwent desert training in November-December, and moved to front line in early January 1942. Reinforced with 200th Guards Brigade by end of year. Overall confidence: 78% - strong data on command, deployment, tank types and brigade structure; gaps in precise personnel numbers and some support unit designations.
